column20:
1) Documentation (and to a lesser extent software) is catered too much to creators of Frictionless Data. I think there is a need to provide documentation to *users* of Frictionless Data that answers the question: "I stumbled on this Frictionless Dataset. What is that? How can I read it into something I'm familiar with (dataframe, database)?"
2) Although I appreciate the efforts towards a Frictionless Framework, I think the scope is too wide and as a result spread too thin. In my opinion, Frictionless Data is a means, not an end. Frictionless software should reflect that: it should provide fast functions to read, validate and create Frictionless data and then get out of the way. I would for example keep transformation functions out of scope, as these are better served by other frameworks (Pandas, dplyr, SQL).

Note: I think the Frictionless Standards are excellent (and well documented).
column23: Allowing schema_sync for Table Schema at a specification level. That would allow one to validate dataset against community-approved Table Schemas, which would be a huge boon to interoperability.
column32: Frictionless is the only professional community I know that uses Discord. I would have preferred Slack.
column38: Even though the Frictionless Standards have been around for a couple of years now, I was surprised to discover how small the Frictionless Community feels (at least that is my impression via Discord). I wonder if that impression reflects reality and if so, how the community could collaborate with bigger partners (from e.g. the scientific community) to truly adopt Frictionless Standards in a substantial way.

column20: To be honest I just think that good documentation is hard and not necessarily will be produced by the core team (ie. I consider stackoverflow a form of documentation)

column32: I still resent the choice of using Discord: it's Terms of Service are awful (ranked the lowest possible "E" grade by ToS;DR) and I can't agree with them, so I won't create an account. I hope one day you can at least create a Space in Matrix and bridge it with the current Discord "server". https://herrmann.tech/en/blog/2021/08/10/my-discord-with-discord-or-choosing-alternatives-with-better-terms-of-service.html

column20: Some things in the site/doc are confusing. At first, I seem to recall everything being yaml, then suddenly there was json everywhere with no explanation (was there a switch ? Both seem still supported). Despite looking everywhere, I couldn't find the doc on how to write one's own profile (which seems necessary in order to make field specific "standards"). The site is already huge and it is hard to orient in it, despite clear efforts in that direction: it is hard to find the information one searches: do I need the framework, the libraries, the components, how does one get to the specs site ?
column23: I am wondering how I could get colleagues who are not programmers at all to use frictionless.
